channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pilot Spoke to Air Controllers After Shutoff of Data System
item.description: Malaysia’s defense minister said Sunday that the captain of the missing Malaysia Airlines plane radioed to air traffic control without indicating trouble shortly after a data signaling system on the plane was disabled.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A Malaysian soldier patrolled an area of the airport in Kuala Lumpur where passengers have written messages for the people aboard the missing plane and their loved ones.

item.title: Kerry Presses Russia on ‘Provocations’ in Ukraine
item.description: In his second call in two days to his Russian counterpart, Secretary of State John Kerry expressed concerns about the seizure of a gas plant near the border of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: An Engineering Landmark Faces Demolition in Moscow
item.description: Architects, engineers and preservationists are fighting to save the Shabolovka radio tower, considered the Eiffel Tower of Moscow and now on track for demolition.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN
item.media:description: The Shabolovka radio tower in Moscow.

item.title: Parents of Japanese Woman Kidnapped by North Korea Meet Their Granddaughter
item.description: The parents of the woman, who was kidnapped in 1977 and is believed to have died in 1994, saw their North Korean-born granddaughter for the first time last week in Ulan Bator, Mongolia.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Shigeru and Sakie Yokota in 2010 in Japan. Their daughter, Megumi Yokota, disappeared when she was 13.

item.title: Syrian Forces Seize Key Town From Rebels
item.description: Government forces, backed by Hezbollah fighters, took control of Yabrud, a critical transit point for militants, refugees and arms heading in and out of Lebanon.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Under Watch of Russian Troops, Crimea Votes on Secession
item.description: With the outcome of the referendum on secession from Ukraine almost a foregone conclusion, the greater suspense lay in how swiftly the West would levy threatened sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman cast her ballot in the Crimean referendum on Sunday in Simferopol, Ukraine.

item.title: India Suspends Its Search for Flight 370
item.description: After scouring more than 24,000 nautical square miles, India on Sunday halted its search in the Indian Ocean while officials in Kuala Lumpur consider where else to look.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: News Analysis: China’s Currency Is No Longer a One-Way Bet
item.description: Recent developments suggest that the renminbi’s day-to-day strengthening is no longer the certainty it once appeared to be.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH

item.title: Executions Delayed for Two in India Gang Rape Case
item.description: The Supreme Court in India issued a stay of execution for two of the four men convicted of the gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old student on a bus in 2012.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Series of Errors by Malaysia Mounts, Complicating the Task of Finding Flight 370
item.description: A week after the plane disappeared, the trail is even colder as the search now sprawls from the snowy peaks of the Himalayas to the empty expanses of the southern Indian Ocean.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: In Colombia, Two Warring Officials Provide a Portrait of a Nation’s Political Divide
item.description: A conflict that arose after the country’s powerful inspector general ordered the mayor of Bogotá removed from office has captivated Colombians.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters flooded a central square to defend Mayor Gustavo Petro of Bogotá, after Alejandro Ordóñez, the Colombian inspector general, ordered him removed from office in December.

item.title: Russia Seizes Gas Plant Near Crimea Border, Ukraine Says
item.description: On the eve of a secession referendum in Crimea, Russian forces took a natural gas terminal while Western officials prepared sanctions for Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN, PETER BAKER and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armed forces patrolled a checkpoint on a road between Sevastopol and Simferopol in Crimea on Saturday.

item.title: As Putin’s Popularity Soars, Voices of Opposition Are Being Drowned Out
item.description: While the world’s attention is trained on Ukraine, the Russian authorities are trying to mobilize support on federal television channels, and have muted independent voices on the Internet.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

item.title: Passengers and Crew of Missing Plane Scrutinized for Aviation Skills
item.description: The focus of the investigation returned to two people on board with expertise — the pilot and his first officer.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: The home of Fariq Abdul Hamid, 27, the first officer on the missing Malaysia Airlines flight, about 15 miles west of Kuala Lumpur.

item.title: Transgender Models Prosper in Brazil, Where Carnival and Faith Reign
item.description: Transgender models are enjoying success in Brazil, where crossing gender lines is increasingly accepted, but they say that the nation’s conservatism can also create a hostile environment.
item.dc:creator: By TAYLOR BARNES
item.media:credit: Lianne Milton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Felipa Tavares, 26, a transgender model, during a photo shoot in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Syrian Forces Close to Taking Over Long-Held Rebel Town
item.description: Government forces, backed by the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, have spent weeks edging toward Yabrud, a critical transit point for militants, refugees and arms heading in and out of Lebanon.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Tensions Flare Over Loyalty to Russia in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Nationalist and pro-secessions groups clashed in Kharkiv, a major city in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Sentence Cut for Bin Laden Figure
item.description: A doctor, convicted in Pakistan of treason for helping the C.I.A. track down Osama bin Laden, had 10 years cut from his 33-year sentence.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Investigators in Jet Search Rely on an Imperfect Tool
item.description: Lacking typical ways like radar and radio reports from the crew to track the missing Malaysian plane, searchers are left with an hourly electronic “handshake” between the plane and a satellite.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:description: Relatives of Chinese passengers aboard the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 listened in a hotel in Beijing to a news conference by Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia on Saturday.

item.title: Russia Vetoes U.N. Resolution on Crimea
item.description: Proposed by the United States, the Security Council measure declaring Sunday’s planned secession vote illegal received one no vote. China abstained.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: China’s Central Bank Allows Its Currency More Volatility
item.description: The bank doubled the amount by which the renminbi would be permitted to rise or fall each day, making it more responsive to market forces.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Paralympics, at Peace as Wars Wind Down
item.description: The reality of the Paralympics’ rise over the past decade could be seen in the biographies of so many of its athletes: former soldiers gravely wounded on far-flung battlefields.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SHPIGEL
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Soule, a veteran United States soldier, in a sit-ski sprint last week at the Paralympics in Russia.

item.title: News Analysis: Israel Reaches Out to the Diaspora
item.description: It feels more comfortable asking for help and more supportive of Jews abroad.
item.dc:creator: By ETHAN BRONNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: In recent years, Beit Shemesh, a city of 80,000 near Jerusalem, has become the scene of conflicts between secular and ultra-Orthodox Israelis. Its population is about evenly split between the two groups.

item.title: Melba Hernández, a Confidante of Castro From First Volley, Is Dead at 92
item.description: Ms. Hernández became one of the first four members of Fidel Castro’s general staff and helped him during the Cuban revolution.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Melba Hernández and Fidel Castro at the 1999 burial of a fellow revolutionary, Jesus Montane, whom she married.

item.title: Malaysia Officials Open Criminal Inquiry Into Missing Jet
item.description: Prime Minister Najib Razak said in a news conference that data indicated that someone took action to change the course of the plane, which traveled for seven hours after it lost contact with ground control.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Malaysian and Japanese crews searched for the missing Malaysian flight over the waters of the South China Sea on Saturday.
